2.
a lot of large
and their baggage were boad
ed then and they were rowed ashore in the dark. I looked down on tham
heee chin. He caught hold of the rope and pulled and beat on the box
with his hands and smiled and was having a swell time. - after spend
ding ten hours between decks in a situation that must have been at
least somewhat like the Black Hole of Calcutta. I thought to
myself
"Sonny you may live to be a coolie, or you may not live at all, but
just now you are a man and I take my hat off to you." I decided I
would get to Kowan all right and there would be nothing to it.
Yes terday about two P.M., after giving notice, the Jap-
anes e started outn to demolish Nantao because there are some Chin-
ese troops there who were eut off and will not surrender.
I stood on
to p of the Dollar Building and
watched airplanes drop fifty to ah
hundred bombs and heard the artillery from near Jessfieldshelling it,
firing over the city. It was rather depressing. Nantao is surrounded
on the North, East and West by the Whangppoo and the French Concession
in all they could,
ession. So Nantao
took it. But it isn't my idea of a war. Just coward-
ly murder. The shelling by the artillery kept up all night at long
intervals, just to keep the civilians happy I suppose. However to
foreigners Shanghei is entirely safe and as soon as this Nantao bu-
siness is over that will be the end of the fighting in the near vici-
nity. When our boat passed around Woosung, we estimated there were one
mostly transports, anchored in the river.
I got a message two days ago from Bix in Nanking, saying he was
leaving for Hankow and for me to meet him there and to go via Hong
Ko ng, but I decided I could make it this way Quicker, s o I am on
my way. The result of the present condition of the war will be that
American boats will soon be calling at Shanghai I think. The Chinese
say they are just starting, but I don't know. Will write you fully
from Hankow.
On board the s.s.
Changsha
I think it is
Nov. 14th
We made it, but what a trip! That is we got from Nant
tungch ow around to Kowan, got aboard another Bos steamer and are
now on our way to Nanking.
The next morning after the first part of
the enclosed letter was written it started drizzling and the weather
was awful. We went ashore about ten A.M. as the B&S agent had told
us no cars were permitted by the military to start out before noon.
By ten it was raining and no cars were permitted to go at all, but
we learned that a convo y of about eight cars had started about six
thirty A.M.
before the rain started. The damned fool English agent
was the dumbest most impossible
couldn't get started. The first nigh t we arrived and he came aboard
he told us we could get cars the next day at noon provided it didnt
rain. When one of the passengers suggested we
ought to get started
ANNONISAOS
